action.action-desc: Mr. Fulcher (for himself and Mr. Simpson) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Accountability

form.official-title: To improve communication between the United States Postal Service and local communities relating to the relocation and establishment of Postal Service retail service facilities, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Mandating Advisable and Informed Locations and Solutions Act or the MAILS Act.

clause.text: may have responsibility for processing and distribution of mail for other such facilities in the surrounding geographic area; and

subparagraph.text: includes a remotely managed post office, a part-time post office, and an administrative post office.

paragraph.text: The term Postal Service means the United States Postal Service.

The term temporary relocation means a temporary relocation of retail services from a post office to support Postal Service business for a holiday, special event, or overflow business, as described in paragraph (a)(2)(i) of section 241.4 of title 39, Code of Federal Regulations.

section.text: Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Postal Service shall establish by regulation a formal process for a local government official to request a new post office within the locality.

section.header: Communication relating to post office relocation
section.text: The Postal Service shall amend section 241.4 of title 39, Code of Federal Regulations, to provide the following:

paragraph.text: The Postal Service may not implement a temporary relocation, including for a commemorative event, for a period longer than 2 days without collecting and considering community input under paragraph (c) of that section.

subparagraph.text: Not later than 30 days before the date of a temporary relocation, the Postal Service shall—

clause.text: submit to 1 or more local elected officials in the area in which the affected post office is located a written outline of the proposal; and
offer to discuss the proposal with the elected official under paragraph (c) of that section.
not later than 15 days before the date of a temporary relocation, provide public notice of the temporary relocation in the area in which the affected post office is located; and
not later than 15 days after providing notice to local elected officials under subparagraph (A)(i), hold a public presentation under paragraph (c) of that section.

paragraph.text: Not later than 60 days after the end of the initial 30-day comment period under paragraph (c) of that section, and every 60 days thereafter until the date that is 60 days after the last day of a temporary relocation, the Postal Service shall submit to relevant local government officials updates on the status of the temporary relocation.

subsection.text: With respect to any temporary relocation for a period that is longer than 180 days (whether due to the originally projected length of the relocation or due to an extension), not later than 30 days after the first day of the temporary relocation (or of the extension that caused the length of the relocation to exceed 180 days, if applicable), the Postal Service shall submit a report relating to the temporary relocation or extension to—

paragraph.text: the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate;
the Committee on Oversight and Accountability of the House of Representatives; and
the members of Congress who represent the congressional district or State in which the affected post office is located.

subsection.text: Each report described in subsection (a) shall include a discussion of—

paragraph.text: whether the communication requirements were met within the required timelines, and if not, an explanation for the failure to comply with the requirements; and
whether the period of the temporary relocation is being extended, and if so, an explanation for the extension.
